sections.title: Classification and Evolution
sections.summary: All living things are identified and categorised on the basis of their body design in form and function.

sections.title: The Hierarchy of Classification-
sections.summary: Groups Biologists, such as Ernst Haeckel (1894), Robert Whittaker (1969) and Carl Woese (1977) have tried to classify all living organisms into broad categories, called kingdoms.

sections.title: 1MONERA
sections.summary: These organisms do not have a defined nucleus or organelles, nor do any of them show multi-cellular body designs.

sections.title: 2PROTISTA
sections.summary: This group includes many kinds of unicellular eukaryotic organisms.

sections.title: 3FUNGI
sections.summary: These are heterotrophic eukaryotic organisms.

sections.title: 4PLANTAE
sections.summary: These are multicellular eukaryotes with cell walls.

sections.title: 5ANIMALIA
sections.summary: These include all organisms which are multicellular eukaryotes without cell walls.

sections.title: Plantae
sections.summary: The first level of classification among plants depends on whether the plant body has well- differentiated, distinct parts.

sections.title: 1THALLOPHYTA
sections.summary: Plants that do not have well-differentiated body design fall in this group.

sections.title: 2BRYOPHYTA
sections.summary: These are called the amphibians of the plant kingdom.

sections.title: 3PTERIDOPHYTA
sections.summary: In this group, the plant body is differentiated into roots, stem and leaves and has specialised tissue for the conduction of water and other substances from one part of the plant body to another.

sections.title: 4 GYMNOSPERMS
sections.summary: This term is derived from two Greek words: gymno– means naked and sperma– means seed.

sections.title: 5 ANGIOSPERMS
